heading: online textbook shops get a+
subheading: that recurring hell for the college student -- waiting in line at the bookstore, hoping the required reading is in stock, and paying outrageous sums of money for it -- just got a whole lot easier.
author: reuters
text: it may be the world's biggest bookstore, but even amazon doesn't stock titles such as  applied linear algebra, foundations of euclidean geometry, and medically important fungi.just when it seemed e-commerce leaders barnesandnoble.com and amazon had the online bookselling business all sewn up, a few start-up companies have found a niche in textbooks.varsitybooks.com in washington and bigwords in san francisco specialize not in books from the bestseller list, but in the more obscure volumes found on college syllabi.another firm, efollett.com of oak brook, illinois, lures students with the slogan, "why get in line, when you can get online?"all say they have attracted thousands of students around the country who buy required reading from web sites rather than the campus store."it wasn't so long ago i was waiting in a long line at the school bookstore paying what i thought was a ridiculous price for my college textbooks," says eric kuhn, the 28-year-old chief executive officer of varsitybooks.com.after a short-lived career as a lawyer, kuhn co-founded varsitybooks just over a year ago on the theory that consolidating text sales online could cut student costs up to 40 percent."the economics of selling textbooks over the internet are basically the same as with popular consumer books, except the potential to cut costs is much greater," matt johnson, president and co-founder of bigwords, says.the textbook business is highly fragmented with a multitude of small academic presses publishing books on economics, biology, accounting, and so forth. course material can vary significantly from campus to campus, with professors often assigning little-known texts they wrote themselves. this leaves college bookstores scrambling to get the merchandise from a variety of sources at high sales and shipping costs."there was no aggregator you could just go to and buy all your textbooks in one stop," says johnson, 23, who began looking for a promising internet business idea when he graduated from college two years ago. "we quickly realized that there was a huge opportunity to offer a service that could be incredibly valuable to students."it doesn't take a double major to see opportunities in selling textbooks online. textbooks are a us$3-billion-a-year market, and students are a captive audience since most reading material is required. plus, the college student population is an especially net-savvy group. the extra credit: when they convene in one site, there's a good chance advertisers will follow."it's a very sought-after demographic. students in college are making decisions about what they will do for the rest of their life -- in terms of what credit card they use, what brand of shaving cream, what airline they fly. but traditionally this has been a frustratingly fragmented market," kuhn says.still, the two companies differ when it comes to their business plans. varsitybooks.com doesn't aim to sell every single textbook published. instead, it works with hundreds of colleges and universities to offer all their undergraduate course-books lists, about 400,000 titles to date.
